intro: Siphocampylus williamsii, commonly known as Williams' siphocampylus, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and umbel-like inflorescences. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in arid or semi-arid environments. Its small, white to pale yellow flowers bloom in the spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
